GER 1.title: Elementary German
GER 1.prereq_description: Not open for credit to students who have completed more advanced work in German.
GER 1.description: Beginning course in German. Student acquires the basic structure of the language, communicative skills, a limited general vocabulary, correct pronunciation, and an ability to read and understand simple cultural texts.

GER 1G.title: Introduction to Reading German (for Graduate Students)
GER 1G.description: First part of a two-quarter sequence that introduces graduate students to the essentials of the German language with emphasis on aspects of structure that are indispensable for reading skills. Translation of academic, literary, philosophical, scientific, and journalistic texts. Open to students with graduate standing in any field.

GER 2.title: Elementary German
GER 2.prereq_description: Grade of P or grade of C or better in German 1.  Not open for credit to students who have completed more advanced work in German.

GER 2G.title: Introduction to Reading German (for Graduate Students)
GER 2G.description: Course is a continuation of German 1G, using the same approach, with reading texts on a more complex level.

GER 3.title: Elementary German
GER 3.prereq_description: Grade of P or grade of C or better in German 2.  Not open for credit to students who have completed more advanced work in German.

GER 4.title: Intermediate German
GER 4.prereq_description: Grade of P or grade of C or better in German 3.  Not open for credit to students who have completed more advanced work in German.
GER 4.description: Continuation of German 3. Expansion and refinement of linguistic and communicative skills leaned in Beginning German. Greater focus on speaking German with fluency and accuracy, reading short authentic texts, and writing coherent, organized essays.

GER 5.title: Intermediate German
GER 5.prereq_description: Grade of P or grade of C or better in German 4.  Not open for credit to students who have completed more advanced work in German.

GER 6.title: Intermediate German
GER 6.prereq_description: Grade of P or grade of C or better in German 5.  Not open for credit to students who have completed more advanced work in German.

GER 8A.title: Beginning German Conversation
GER 8A.description: Course designed to offer beginning German language students communicative strategies needed by speakers and listeners in face-to face interaction. Not open to students with native fluency in German.

GER 8B.title: Beginning German Conversation
GER 8B.description: Course designed to offer beginning German language students communicative strategies needed by speakers and listeners in face-to-face interaction. Not open to students with native fluency in German.

GER 8C.title: Beginning German Conversation
GER 8C.description: Course designed to offer beginning German language students communicative strategies needed by speakers and listeners in face-to-face interaction. Not open to students with native fluency in German.

GER 31.title: Doubles: Film and Literature
GER 31.description: When the double is visualized in film, the double's mention or description disappears from the typeface of literature. At the same time it takes center stage or screen in psychoanalytic theory.

GER 35.title: The Making of the Modern World
GER 35.description: Description and analysis of decisive events contributing to the world we are inhabiting. Various themes presented: City planning, war and industrial warfare, technology and media-  technology, ideologies of modernity, and modern master theories.

GER 43A.title: Dreaming Revolutions: Introduction to Marx, Nietzsche and Freud
GER 43A.comments: Same course as Comparative Literature 43A. Not open for credit to students who have completed German 41.
GER 43A.description: Introduction to the revolutionary theories of Karl Marx, Friedrich Nietzsche and Sigmund Freud. Explorations of three authors whose writing has profoundly changed our world.

GER 55A.title: Contemporary German Pop Culture
GER 55A.description: Study of contempory film, music, and other facets of pop culture that have shaped the lifestyle of today's nation of Germany. Study of pop music from 1989 to today and its impact on the new emerging society of post-Wall Germany, focusing on the pointed, humorous, and sometimes scathing lyrics and pop music's ties to German youth culture.

GER 55B.title: Contemporary German Pop Culture
GER 55B.description: Study of contempory film, music, and other facets of pop culture that have shaped the lifestyle of today's nation of Germany. Study of contemporary German cinema since 1970, exploring cinematic representations of issues such as immigration, opposition to East Germany's regime, National Socialism and the Shoah, racism, and sexuality.

GER 95A.title: Elementary Yiddish
GER 95A.description: An introduction to the Yiddish language. The goal is to convey the rediments of the grammar, and to acquire the ability both to read printed Yiddish and to read and write cursive Yiddish.

GER 95B.title: Intermediate Yiddish
GER 95B.description: Continuation of German 95A with further exposure to th grammar of Yiddish. More attention given to standard literary figures (Sholem Aleichem, Peretz,etc.) and their easier works.

GER 95C.title: Advanced Yiddish
GER 95C.description: Continuation of German 95B with advanced grammatical study emphasis on literary texts of some maturity and difficulty as well as contemporary Yiddish in this country, both journalistic and literary.

GER 101A.title: Advanced German
GER 101A.description: Speaking, listening, reading, and writing on an advanced level, while exploring contemporary German culture. Systematic review of grammar material. Additional focus on vocabulary building. Written and oral discussions based on newspaper articles, literary texts, German films, and websites. Topics will vary by quarter.

GER 101B.title: Advanced German
GER 101B.description: Speaking, listening, reading, and writing on an advanced level, while exploring contemporary German culture. Systematic review of grammar material. Additional focus on vocabulary building. Written and oral discussions based on newspaper articles, literary texts, German films, and websites. Topics will vary by quarter.

GER 101C.title: Advanced German
GER 101C.description: Speaking, listening, reading, and writing on an advanced level, while exploring contemporary German culture. Systematic review of grammar material. Additional focus on vocabulary building. Written and oral discussions based on newspaper articles, literary texts, German films, and websites. Topics will vary by quarter.

GER 104.title: German Language and Society
GER 104.description: Structural and sociolinguistic study of contemporary German from a descriptive linguistic perspective. Primary topics include: phonetic and phonological features of spoken German, syntax, regional variation and dialect, and colloquial varieties of German. No background in linguistics is presumed; taught in German.

GER 105C.title: Advanced Conversation
GER 105C.description: Emphasizes interactional strategies needed for communication in German, while also giving intermediate and advanced students the opportunity to discuss a wide variety of topics. Not open to students with native fluency in German.

GER 106.title: Advanced Reading and Writing Skills
GER 106.comments: Open to non-majors. Quarters usually offered: Fall.
GER 106.description: Focus on the development of advanced reading and writing skills in German. In particular, we will draw on a variety of authentic materials to develop students' ability to analyze and produce a range of genres; enhance students' awareness of pre-, during- and post-reading strategies and how to apply them to different styles of writing; improve use of strategies to help students become more autonomous readers/writers; and develop critical skills for reading, comprehending, and writing different types of texts.

GER 107A.title: History of Culture
GER 107A.description: Careful and close readings from the cultural history of German speaking countries. Materials, which may be revised each academic year, include documents from literature, philosophy, art, music, architecture, science, politics, and law. Taught in German.

GER 107B.title: History of Culture
GER 107B.description: Careful and close readings from the cultural history of German speaking countries. Materials, which may be revised each academic year, include documents from literature, philosophy, art, music, architecture, science, politics, and law. Taught in German.

GER 107C.title: History of Culture
GER 107C.description: Careful and close readings from the cultural history of German speaking countries. Materials, which may be revised each academic year, include documents from literature, philosophy, art, music, architecture, science, politics, and law. Taught in German.

GER 108.description: In the wake of reunification, Germany has struggled to come to terms with its changing political identity and pressing cultural issues, including Germany's contested status as a "nation of immigrants," extremism, environmental problems, and government surveillance. A variety of media actively engage with these issues, particularly within youth culture. This course analyzes how established and emerging media (literature, music, television, film, video, blogs, etc) shape and respond to the challenges of the day. Taught in German.

GER 109AAZZ.title: Current Trends in German Culture and Literature
GER 109AAZZ.comments:
Open to non-majors.
Repeat Comments: Course may be repeated provided letter designations are different.
GER 109AAZZ.description: Introduces students to current trends in German cultural, political, and literary studies. Topics might include new interpretations of canonical texts, contemporary debates about political & ethical questions, developments in literature, media, and the arts. In English.

GER 111.title: Contemporary German Art and Politics
GER 111.description: Introduces students to contemporary German culture with a focus on political thinking and artistic production. Topics will include post-reunification Germany, immigration politics, and the question of a "German" identity. Taught in English.

GER 112.title: Introduction to German Culture
GER 112.comments: Open to non-majors. Quarters usually offered: Spring.
GER 112.description: German thinkers and artists shaped Western culture, leaving their mark on the history of art, science, and politics. This course familiarizes students with key events in German history and culture and the most important figures in the modern Western tradition.

GER 113.title: Special Topics in German Literature
GER 113.description: In-depth study of special topics in literary texts of German-speaking traditions. Topics will vary by instructor. Topics may include: "Science in German Literature," "Literature and human rights," "Animals in literature," "Literature and the environment." Taught in German.

GER 114.title: Business German
GER 114.description: German is a key language in the European Union and the developing economies of Central and Eastern Europe. Speaking German greatly improves chances of success in today's global economy.  Course is an introduction to the language typically used in business settings within German-speaking countries. It will better prepare students for business-related situations and will provide them a clearer understanding of German corporate culture by covering topics such as the application process, Emails, phone conversations, meetings, business trips.

GER 115A.title: Survey of German Literature
GER 115A.description: Survey of the literary movements of the twentieth century.

GER 115B.title: Survey of German Literature
GER 115B.description: Survey of the literature of classicism and romanticism.

GER 115C.title: Survey of German Literature
GER 115C.description: Survey of the literary movements of the nineteenth century.

GER 116A.title: Representations of the Holocaust
GER 116A.description: Close reading of post-Holocaust literature. Taught in English.

GER 117.title: Special Topics in German Culture
GER 117.description: In-depth study of special topics important for an understanding of German culture, drawing on a broad range of print and visual media, music and architecture. Topics will vary by instructor and may include: "Violence and Society", "Activist Cultures," "Sports and Nationalism," "Dissident Voices," "The politics of music," "Theater in German speaking countries."  Taught in German.

GER 143.title: The Superhuman
GER 143.description: Our ongoing technologization received two theoretical frames by the end of the nineteenth century: first the theory of evolution, then psychoanalysis.In this double setting, the fantasy of the superhuman has been opening up new prospects for man-and-god.

GER 151C.title: Literature of Central Europe
GER 151C.comments: Same course as Slavic 151C and Comparative Literature 161.
GER 151C.description: Investigation of the prolific literatures of central Europe, one of the culturally and linguistically most diverse regions of the European continent that has produced writers such as Italo Svevo, Franz Kafka, Robert Musil, Bruno Schultz, and others. Readings in English.

GER 152.title: Digital Humanities Practice
GER 152.description: In the 21st century, scholars have increasingly turned to computational methods for the analysis of large corpora of art and literature. While early methods of "distant reading" and "distant viewing" could be realized with off-the-shelf software, contemporary research in the digital humanities requires technical skills beyond ready-made tools. This course provides an introduction to computer programming for the humanities, including, but not limited to concepts from natural language processing, computer vision, and machine learning.

GER 155.title: Critical Artificial Intelligence
GER 155.description: Artificial intelligence now affects nearly all aspects of human life and knowledge production, from labor to language, and from fundamental physics to the arts. The pivotal role of the humanities lies in the critical analysis of the specific cultural techniques emerging from this technical revolution: new methods of language processing, image production, scientific reasoning, and social control require new critical and historical approaches. This course provides an introduction to the history and theory of artificial intelligence from the perspective of the humanities. Participants will acquire the skills to analyze and understand the design and construction of machine learning systems, and their philosophical and political implications.

GER 161.title: Classicism and Romanticism in German Literature
GER 161.description: Selected readings in English translation from the classical and romantic German authors of the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries.

GER 163.title: Digital Visual Studies
GER 163.comments: Same course as Comparative Literature 163 and History of Art and Architecture 163.
GER 163.description: In the past ten years, the scope of the digital humanities has broadened to include the visual world: "distant reading" became "distant viewing". This visual turn has not only facilitated the digital transformation of traditional disciplines like art history but has also introduced a new set of media-technological questions into the digital humanities discourse: questions concerning the nature of digital images, and the modalities of machine seeing. This course serves as an introduction to the emerging discipline of "digital visual studies" that investigates these questions. Participants will acquire skills in the analysis and critique of digital visual culture and learn to use contemporary digital tools to explore the visual world.

GER 164E.title: Major Works in German Literature: Kafka
GER 164E.description: A selection of Franz Kafka's novels, short stories and diaries will be closely read and analyzed. Readings, lecture and discussion in English.

GER 164F.title: Major Works in German Literature: Nietzsche
GER 164F.description: A selection of Friedrich Nietzsche's prolific philosophical oeuvre will be closely read and analyzed. Readings, lecture and discussion in English.

GER 164G.title: Major Works in German Literature: Freud
GER 164G.description: A  selection of Sigmund Freud's prolific theoretical oeuvre, as well as several case studies will be closely read and analyzed. Readings, lecture and discussion in English.

GER 164H.title: Major Works in German Literature: Heidegger
GER 164H.description: A selection of Martin Heidegger's prolific philosophical oeuvre will be closely read and analyzed. Readings, lecture and discussion in English.

GER 177A.title: Law, Rights, and Justice
GER 177A.description: Focused on the question of justice, this course will cover a wide variety of topics ranging from the detective novel, and literary texts inspired by criminal cases, to legal philosophy, human rights, and international law. Source materials may include a few documents from Greek and Roman Antiquity as well as passages from the bible, but the emphasis is on German literary, legal, and philosophical texts from the eighteenth century to the present. Taught in German.

GER 179A.title: Revolutions: Marx, Nietzsche, Freud
GER 179A.description: Marx, Nietzsche, and Freud have revolutionized our world: Marx, the political and economic landscape; Nietzsche, the realm of philosophy and literature; and Freud, the way we think of our mind, sexualities, wishes and dreams. Explorations of three revolutionary challenges.

GER 179B.title: Mysticism
GER 179B.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed German 169. Same course as Comparative Literature 179B and Religious Studies 179B.
GER 179B.description: Analysis of German mystical writing, its roots in ancient Greek texts, revolutionary impact, links with other mystical traditions, and influence on secular literature. Texts include Hildegard von Bingen, Meister Eckhart, Mechthild von Magdeburg, Novalis, Rilke, etc. Taught in English.

GER 179C.title: Mediatechnology
GER 179C.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed German 180.
GER 179C.description: Telegraph, telephone, phonograph, and film are techniques that have engendered new forms of representation, communication, and thinking. Course studies the impact of these transformations in literature and on literature. Taught in English.

GER 185.title: Science and Technology in European Philosophy
GER 185.description: Introduces various positions from the history and present of European philosophy that speak to questions of science and technology. Readings may include Aristotle, Descartes, Kant, Nietzsche, Freud, Heidegger, Arendt, Bachelard, Koyré, Caillois, Foucault, Canguilhem, Blumenberg, Serres, Malabou, Stiegler. Topics may include: machine theories, cybernetics, structuralism in science, techniques of simulation, artificial intelligence.

GER 187.title: The Devil in Literature
GER 187.description: Explores the rich literature around making deals with the devil while focusing on the enduring influence of older literature on modern conceptions of the diabolic.

GER 190.title: Proseminar
GER 190.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units, but only 4 units may be applied toward the major.
GER 190.description: Intensive advanced seminar on topic to be determined on a quarterly basis. Taught in German.

GER 197.title: Senior Honors Project
GER 197.prereq_description: Open to senior majors only; consent of instructor.
GER 197.comments: Students must have a 3.0 overall grade-point average and a 3.5 grade-point average in the major.
GER 197.description: An independent study course (one to three quarters) directed by a faculty member with a carefully chosen topic and bibliography which will result in a documented project or a senior thesis.

GER 198.title: Readings in German
GER 198.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in German.
GER 198.comments: Students must have a minimum 3.0 grade-point average for the preceding three quarters. Students are limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined.
GER 198.description: Independent studies in German. Individual investigations in literary fields. Readings in German.

GER 199.title: Independent Studies in German
GER 199.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in German.
GER 199.comments: Students must have a minimum 3.0 grade-point average for the preceding three quarters. Students are limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined.

GER 199RA.title: Independent Research Assistance in German
GER 199RA.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 courses in upper-division German; consent of instructor and department.
GER 199RA.comments: Students must have a 3.0 grade-point average for the preceding three quarters. Students are limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined.
GER 199RA.description: Coursework shall consist of faculty supervised research assistance.

GER 210.title: Seminar in Literary Theory and Criticism
GER 210.description: Topics in literary theory to be determined on a quarterly basis.

GER 262A.title: Applied Linguistics
GER 262A.description: Overview of the basic theoretical principles of second language acquisition as they apply to language teaching and learning. Discussion of different methodologies of foreign language teaching and the history of those used in the U.S.; special emphasis on current methodologies.

GER 270.title: Theories of the Modern
GER 270.description: Analysis of theories and critiques of modernism and modernity from Benjaminto Adorno and Derrida, with special focus on the historical avantgarde.

GER 500.title: Practicum for Teaching Assistants
GER 500.comments: Units earned in this course, which is required of all teaching assistants, do not apply toward completion of the M.A. or Ph.D. requirement.
GER 500.description: Subject oriented, designed to relate directly to the teaching of a particular course in progress, to improve the skills and effectiveness of the department's teaching assistants.

GER 596.title: Directed Reading and Research
GER 596.prereq_description: German 210A-B or equivalent. Graduate standing; consent of instructor, graduate adviser and department chair.
GER 596.description: Individualized instruction. A written proposa must be approved by department chair, to include a description of the course content and a reading list.

GER 597.title: Individual Study for Master's Comprehensive Examinations and Ph.D. Examinations
GER 597.prereq_description: German 201A-B or equivalent. Graduate standing; consent of graduate adviser
GER 597.comments: No unit credit allowed toward advanced degree(s). Enrollment limited to 12 units per examination.
GER 597.description: Instructor should normally be the student's major professor or chair of thedoctoral committee. Enrollment must be approved by graduate adviser.

GER 598.title: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation
GER 598.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units, but only 4 units may be applied toward master's degree in german.
GER 598.description: Instructor should be chair of student's thesis committee.

GER 599.title: Ph.D. Dissertation Research and Preparation
GER 599.prereq_description: German 201A-B or equivalent. Advancement to candidacy; consent of graduate adviser.
GER 599.description: Only for preparation of the dissertation. Instructor should be the chair of the student's doctoral committee.
